awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Impacts of Coastal Flood-Induced Relocation on Local Jurisdictions
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary project studies the impacts of relocation in coastal communities on local jurisdictions. It will provide data about possible consequences of flood-driven depopulation of coastal jurisdictions, including the loss of sociocultural identity and economic viability. This information is imperative to support localities in policy changes that would minimize the adverse effects of flood-induced relocation on their governance and institutional performance. This project serves national interests by advancing science on emerging problems in coastal communities whose resilience is vital for national security, stability, and welfare. Its societal benefits are also achieved by including highly vulnerable coastal communities (e.g. rural fishing villages and urban poor), which are already experiencing various socioeconomic and environmental challenges that may compound their vulnerability. Results and supplemental materials will be disseminated via an online web portal designed to facilitate a community of researchers, practitioners, and other stakeholders interested in coastal resilience. Outreach will be enhanced by the Virginia Cooperative Extension, which has a long history of education in rural communities. 

The goal of this interdisciplinary project is to improve the scientific understanding of possible consequences of coastal flood-induced relocation on local jurisdictions with diverse socio-economic, cultural, institutional, and historic contexts. It will establish scenarios of coastal flood-driven relocation over different time scales in both rural and urban settings to discern potential implications of this process on the socioeconomic viability of local jurisdictions. This mixed-methods approach will rely on both quantitative and qualitative data to capture the contextual influences and complexities that typically shape local decision-making. The project activities will: 1) examine the risk of coastal flooding and develop spatiotemporal flood exposure scenarios of potential loss of businesses, real-estate, and corresponding population; 2) determine preferences for relocation destination among residents living in flood-prone areas obtained via household surveys, and 3) discern emergent macro-scale trends in relocation behavior using Agent Based Modeling (ABM). The analysis will be applied to two contrasting case study locations with different levels of urbanization on the Eastern Shore, Maryland, and in Hampton Roads, Virginia. Important aspects of the research strategy include interdisciplinary integration of geography, coastal and system engineering, and business analytics, as well as holistic analysis of circumstances that may affect the extent and progression of relocation from coastal flood-affected periphery. This project will ultimately lead to improved understanding of how physical, behavioral, and institutional factors interact to shape the evolution of coastal communities under increasing flood risks, thereby leading to more resilient communities in the coastal zone.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this interdisciplinary project titled Assessing the Impacts of Coastal Flood-Induced Relocation on Local Jurisdictions (ID#1920478) was to improve the scientific understanding of possible consequences of flood-induced relocation in coastal jurisdictions with diverse socioeconomic, cultural, institutional, and historical contexts. This research established scenarios of coastal flood-driven relocation in rural and urban settings over different time scales to discern the potential implications of this outcome on coastal communities. It used mixed methods to capture the contextual influences and complexities that typically shape local decision-making in two contrasting case study locations with different levels of urbanization (rural areas on the Eastern Shore in Maryland and urban in Hampton Roads, Virginia). The specific research goals were the identification of coastal flood risk and development of spatiotemporal flood exposure scenarios of potential land use losses, the establishment of weighted pull and push factors of coastal relocation, and the preferences for relocation destinations among residents living in flood-prone areas obtained via household surveys; and determination of emergent macro-scale trends in relocation behavior using Agent-Based Modeling (ABM). This effort has three primary outcomes. First, it developed a probabilistic tropical cyclone flood hazard framework that leverages a convolutional neural network-derived surrogate model for storm surge, joint probability statistics, and sea-level rise projections. Then, it established a broad range of relocation push and pull migration drivers among homeowners living in high-risk flood-prone coastal locations via mail and telephone surveys. Lastly, it created a stochastic Agent-Based Model based on the push-pull migration theory capable of replicating broad-scale population projections for the region out to 2070. This ABM serves as a tool for experimental assessment of impacts stemming from different flood scenarios and assumptions about human behavior.

 

Among the key results, we found that the urban case study areas have a greater 1% Annual Exceedance Probability (AEP) peak storm surge (MSL) than the rural locations. Similarly, they have higher SLR exposure for three-time horizons (2030, 2060, and 2090) than the rural ones. However, the percent change in 1% AEP peak storm surge in response to SLR is smaller in the selected urban areas (26% by 2060) than in rural (41% by 2060). Based on the projected flood risk, exposed coastal urban land uses, such as open space, military and mixed-use, and rural residential and commercial areas, will experience significantly more flooding with significant implications for relocation planning. The mail survey results show that 36% of respondents would already consider permanently relocating due to flooding, with 49% doing so in the future and only 15% not considering relocating. Rural residents are marginally less likely to consider relocation, with 33% versus 39% of urban respondents. Respondents would most likely consider permanent relocation due to flooding if the crime worsens, if the insurance could not cover the property damage, if they experience disastrous or significant flooding and damage to their home or vehicle, and if they are offered financial compensation (buyout). The least important consideration was getting a job in a land/water-based or service industry if they could move together with their neighbors and if they experienced minor flooding. The most important pull towards a receiving destination would be moving closer to family and friends and to hospitals and health care services, amenities, and job opportunities. The telephone survey administered in rural and urban areas revealed that almost 70% of respondents experienced coastal flooding, mostly from extreme weather events, with the highest impacts on school delays and closures, and commuting. Here, only 22% of respondents would consider permanently relocating due to coastal flooding, while 23% would consider doing so in the future. The main predictor of willingness to relocate was the risk of significant flooding from a combination of sources and free legal and technical advice on the respondent’s options for staying versus relocating. Most respondents would consider permanent relocation due to major hurricane disasters, higher taxes, higher costs of living on the coast, and higher insurance rates. The main reasons for selecting the relocation destinations are to move to a place with lower crime rates and better public safety, closer to family, and closer to health services and facilities. The probabilistic tropical cyclone flood hazard framework and surveys were used to inform the development of the Agent-Based Model.

The model demonstrates how changes in the relative importance of flooding in household decision-making impacted the number and demographic distribution of people residing in flood-prone locations under both nuisance and extreme flooding scenarios. In particular, it identified specific geographic locations where flood impacts dampened and amplified ongoing demographic trends occurring at the census tract level (population increases, decreases, and stabilization). It also demonstrates how differences in relocation preferences across income groups and ages impacted the vulnerability profile in flood-prone locations.
